bio:treatment.discussion: Molendoa ogalalensis is known in the flora area from four localities in the central High Plains. It is unusual in the genus in the distal laminal cells having walls of equal thickness both superficially and internally. Other species of the genus commonly have the superficial walls clearly thicker than the internal, though this is not a rule. The large papillae centrally placed on the lumen is reminiscent of Tuerckheimia, which, however, is acrocarpous and has acute leaf apices. Although M. ogalalensis is not easily recognized, the lack of a distinct stem sclerodermis, 2-stratose distal lamina, each lumen with a massive simple or weakly 2-fid papilla, evenly thickened superficial and internal cell walls, and lateral perichaetia are diagnostic. It has a stem central strand (contrary to the original description). Costal stereid cells are commonly absent (the abaxial band is occasionally present).
